articles.headline: Harris and Democrats Lose Their Reluctance to Call Trump a Fascist
articles.snippet: Since Gen. Mark Milley was quoted as saying Donald Trump is “fascist to the core,” a term avoided by top members of the Democratic Party is suddenly everywhere.
articles.abstract: Since Gen. Mark Milley was quoted as saying Donald Trump is “fascist to the core,” a term avoided by top members of the Democratic Party is suddenly everywhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: The word “fascist” has hovered around former President Donald J. Trump from the moment he rode down his golden escalator in 2015 to warn of Mexican rapists and drug dealers in the memorable opening of his bid for president. But for most top Democrats, it was a provocative term loaded with dread, historical import and potential incitement — best left unsaid.

articles.headline: Sinwar Is Dead. Will the Fighting Stop?
articles.snippet: The killing of Hamas’s leader may allow Israel to claim victory and agree to a cease-fire, and new Hamas leadership could be more open to compromise. But neither side is likely to immediately change course.
articles.abstract: The killing of Hamas’s leader may allow Israel to claim victory and agree to a cease-fire, and new Hamas leadership could be more open to compromise. But neither side is likely to immediately change course.
articles.lead_paragraph: For more than a year, the fate of the Hamas leader Yahya Sinwar seemed entwined with the fate of the war in Gaza.

articles.headline: Surprise Battlefield Encounter Led to Hamas Leader’s Death
articles.snippet: Although Yahya Sinwar was a major target of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, the soldiers who killed the militant chief had not expected to run across him, Israeli officials said.
articles.abstract: Although Yahya Sinwar was a major target of Israel’s military campaign in Gaza, the soldiers who killed the militant chief had not expected to run across him, Israeli officials said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Follow our latest updates on the Middle East crisis here.
articles.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Aaron Boxerman, Raja Abdulrahim, Patrick Kingsley and Michael Levenson

articles.headline: Microsoft and OpenAI’s Close Partnership Shows Signs of Fraying
articles.snippet: The “best bromance in tech” has had a reality check as OpenAI has tried to change its deal with Microsoft and the software maker has tried to hedge its bet on the start-up.
articles.abstract: The “best bromance in tech” has had a reality check as OpenAI has tried to change its deal with Microsoft and the software maker has tried to hedge its bet on the start-up.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last fall, Sam Altman, OpenAI’s chief executive, asked his counterpart at Microsoft, Satya Nadella, if the tech giant would invest billions of dollars in the start-up.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Mike Isaac and Erin Griffith

articles.headline: China’s Lackluster Growth Continues, Signaling Why Beijing Acted on Economy
articles.snippet: New data shows the challenges facing Chinese policymakers trying to stimulate an economy marked by falling prices, weak consumer spending and a housing market crash.
articles.abstract: New data shows the challenges facing Chinese policymakers trying to stimulate an economy marked by falling prices, weak consumer spending and a housing market crash.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Chinese economy continued to grow at a lackluster pace over the summer, according to data released on Friday, underscoring the urgency of the government’s recent attempts to bolster growth.

articles.headline: How Is the Economy for Black Voters? A Complex Question Takes Center Stage.
articles.snippet: Donald J. Trump has been talking up his economic record for Black voters. The legacy of the last eight years is complicated.
articles.abstract: Donald J. Trump has been talking up his economic record for Black voters. The legacy of the last eight years is complicated.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 2024 election could be won or lost on the strength of the Black vote, which could in turn be won or lost based on the strength of the American economy. So it is no surprise that candidates are paying a lot of attention — and lip service — to which of the past two administrations did more to improve the lives of Black workers.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Sinwar’s Death Could Shake but Not Topple Hamas, Experts Say
articles.snippet: Analysts call the killing of several Hamas leaders, including Yahya Sinwar, a deep blow to the Palestinian militant group, but expect it to keep fighting.
articles.abstract: Analysts call the killing of several Hamas leaders, including Yahya Sinwar, a deep blow to the Palestinian militant group, but expect it to keep fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: He was there from the early days of Hamas, rose through the ranks to lead the organization and equipped it for the deadliest assault on Israel in its history.

articles.headline: Tesla Self-Driving System Will Be Investigated by Safety Agency
articles.snippet: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it was looking into what Elon Musk’s electric car company called the full self-driving system.
articles.abstract: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said it was looking into what Elon Musk’s electric car company called the full self-driving system.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla’s plan to build fleets of self-driving cars suffered a setback on Friday when the main federal auto safety regulator said it was investigating whether the technology was to blame for four collisions, including one that killed a pedestrian.

articles.headline: Trump Among New York’s Elites at a Charity Dinner: It Got Awkward
articles.snippet: There were grudge matches and sycophancy in equal measure at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. “Isn’t it just exciting, what’s going on,” Donald Trump said.
articles.abstract: There were grudge matches and sycophancy in equal measure at the Alfred E. Smith Memorial Foundation Dinner. “Isn’t it just exciting, what’s going on,” Donald Trump said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald J. Trump and the assorted fat cats to whom he was speaking seemed to be processing many complicated emotions all at once.
